messageBody:
I think I did not explain myself properly.

The TestCase that I created asserts that passed classes possess public
static final fields, that it implement equals(Object) properly as well as
hashCode() and some serialization methods. The classes that I want to test
are constant value classes: NORTH, SOUTH, EAST, etc...

So, I created two classes: One that behaves properly, and one that does
not. I then call my TestCase to test these two class references
(ValidClass.class and InvalidClass.class) to the TestCase constructor. An
example might help:

public class ValidClass {
public static final ValidClass ONE = new ValidClass(1);
private ValidClass(int id) {
this.id = id;
}

public boolean equals(Object o) {
// ...
return (id == o.id);
}

// ... implement hashCode(), readResolve(), etc... properly
}

public class InvalidClass {
public static final InvalidClass ONE = new ValidClass(1);
private InvalidClass(int id) {
this.id = id;
}

public boolean equals(Object o) {
// Make sure that we always fail
return false;
}

// ... implement hashCode(), readResolve(), etc... improperly
}

// One class that is not shown here is TestStaticSerialization that extends
TestCase

// In my TestStaticSerialization TestCase
public void testValidClass() {
TestCase case = TestStaticSerialization(ValidClass.class);

// Should never fail in any of these methods
case.setUp();
case.testEquals();
case.testHashCode();
case.testSerialization();
}

public void testInvalidClass() {
TestCase case = TestStaticSerialization(InvalidClass.class);
case.setUp(); // Should fail here !
case.testEquals();
case.testHashCode();
case.testSerialization();
}

Evidently, I have a few more tests than that, but the general idea is the
same. What I need is to catch the failure on the setUp() call in
testInvalidClass() and change that to a success. I have to do the same on
testEquals(), testHashCode() and testSerialization(). This way, I can
confirm that a valid class (one that properly implements it's equals(Object)
and hashCode() methods) functions properly, and one that does not fails on
the appropriate tests.

I hope this explains everything in a clearer light and that some help might
be provided here.

Thanks !
Francois Beausoleil

I assume you mean a "Class" instance when you say, "an invalid class". In
that case, if you've instantiated a Class successfully, then how can it be
invalid? It certainly represents a valid class, but perhaps that class is
not in the proper hierarchy. My guess is your TestCase either tries to cast
(ClassCastException) or send the class object a message
(NoSuchMethodError). Either way you should get an error/failure reported.

Can you post some sample code to help us understand your problem more
fully?

Thanks.

Hi everyone,

I have this TestCase which I'm testing... Sounds strange, but this is part
of my refactoring work. The TestCase in question receives a class as
parameter, tests some common stuff on it, and returns.

The problem comes when I pass an invalid class. The TestCase should throw
a
failure: Class is null, or does not implement such and such. I am
wondering how I could test for that case. The failure does not seem to
throw an Exception, so I cannot test for that.

Am I right in thinking I will have to implement
junit.framework.TestListener
and listen for appropriate events ?

Thank you,
Francois Beausoleil
